ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned more about the different galleries, exhibits, and treasures at Yale. Also, I learned more about how archival research and research on collections can be done.
How to critically think and analyze, express myself thoughts succinctly, and tackle nuances and contradictions in history and collections.

Every week consisted of doing a deep dive into one of the special collections at Yale. We learn a lot of the history that these collections cover as well as information about archival work as a whole.
Citing sources and how to write a research paper
I learned about the layout and thought behind museums and collections

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Was very well taught and a lot of fun to learn and hear from so many different professionals! Some of the resources were difficult to track down however

Really enjoyed how each class was different and unique. I learned many things about Yale and museums in general. The 2 hour lectures can be a bit long at times, but I definitely prefer having a longer class on one day than two shorter ones.

We only met once a week for a three-hour long seminar. At times this would feel like a lot, but the 10-minute break in the middle of class really helped. Asking question was highly encouraged, and my favorite part of the class. Each class guests (librarians that work with the corresponding collection we were looking at that week) came. As they directly work with the material we were exploring that week, they were more than happy to answer all of the questions we had. They were also equally excited to hear what we had to say about the collections.
The topics we talked about were very interesting.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better canvas organization would be appreciated but otherwise it was all great!
I think because of the pandemic and remote learning, being able to visit so many museums without going in person was really cool.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It was great to be able to learn about the different collections that we visited digitally
Yes! One of the best courses I have taken

I would definitely recommend this class, especially if it takes on an in-person format. Online it was still really interesting, so I remained engaged with each special collection we saw each week. I can only imagine how exciting it would be to be able to visit all the collections in person! There was always something to be learned. In fact, this class has helped me find my new favorite artist (Titus Kaphar) which was very unexpected. In short, this class is an incredibly engaging way to learn both about Yale, but also generally archival work.
Yes because it made me think about museums and collections in different ways

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
